My management is asking me for this too, is this something
that would be ea=
sy to add to junitreport?

Raj


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Ray Kiddy <k=
iddyr@a...> wrote:
> 
> I have found that the best way to do this is probab=
ly with one's 
own 
> TestListener instance.
> 
> I found the facilities fo=
r pointing junit at a bunch of packages 
and 
> having it figure out which =
tests to run to be problematic. It was 
just 
> too fragile, and every time=
 I set things up I got that annoying 
error 
> about the classpath, which s=
eems to be saying "it is your fault, 
and 
> you're an idiot, so don't both=
er us". Once I made my own test 
suite as 
> a static instance, managed the=
 TestResult object myself and added 
a 
> TestListener instance, a whole bu=
nch of this stuff became much, 
much 
> easier.
> 
> Including this.
> 
> T=
he TestListener instance has access to every test as it is run. 
So, at 
> =
that point, you can have something you log, however much of it you 
> want.=
 One can even have an external source of information at that 
> point. We h=
ave a database of our tests and I can query that in the 
> TestListener and=
 annotate the results with whatever stuff I want.
> 
> I frankly do not kno=
w whether junitreport can do these things. But 
it 
> just puts out html. I=
 can do that well enough myself, once i have 
the 
> information.
> 
> - ra=
y
> 
> On Aug 16, 2004, at 9:44 AM, valerie_abelin wrote:
> 
> > I'm using =
Ant to run junit and junitreport.=A0 I like the HTML 
output
> >  that juni=
treport generates, but I am wondering if it is 
possible to
> >  include mo=
re javadoc/comments in the output rather than just the
> >  success/failure=
 status and time the test took to run.=A0 It would 
be
> >  great if junitr=
eport could include a comment from the source 
code
> >  about what each te=
st means.
> >
> >
